text: The vision of Isaiah the son of Amoz, which he saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem in the days of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear, O heavens, and give ear, O earth.
    For the Lord has spoken:
I have nourished and brought up children,
    and they have rebelled against Me;
speaker: Narrator

text:
the ox knows his owner,
    and the donkey his master’s crib,
but Israel does not know;
    My people do not consider.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Alas, sinful nation,
    a people laden with iniquity,
a brood of evildoers,
    children who deal corruptly!
They have forsaken the Lord,
    they have provoked the Holy One of Israel to anger,
    they are estranged and backward.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why should you be beaten again,
    that you revolt more and more?
The whole head is sick,
    and the whole heart faint.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the sole of the foot even to the head
    there is no soundness in it.
Wounds, bruises,
    and open sores;
they have not been closed,
    nor bandaged, nor soothed with oil.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The daughter of Zion is left
    like a shelter in a vineyard,
like a hut in a field of melons,
    like a besieged city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Unless the Lord of Hosts
    had left to us a very small remnant,
we would have been as Sodom;
    we would have been like Gomorrah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear the word of the Lord,
    you rulers of Sodom;
listen to the law of our God,
    you people of Gomorrah:
speaker: Narrator

text:
For what purpose is the multitude
    of your sacrifices to Me? says the Lord.
I am full of the burnt offerings of rams,
    and the fat of fed animals.
I do not delight in the blood of bulls,
    or of lambs, or of male goats.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you come to appear before Me,
    who has required this at your hand,
    to trample My courts?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Bring no more vain offerings;
    incense is an abomination to Me.
New Moons, Sabbaths, and convocations—
    I cannot bear with evil assemblies.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
When you reach out your hands,
    I will hide My eyes from you;
even when you make many prayers,
    I will not hear. 
Your hands are full of blood.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
learn to do good; seek justice,
    relieve the oppressed;
judge the fatherless,
    plead for the widow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come now, and let us reason together,
    says the Lord.
Though your sins be as scarlet,
    they shall be as white as snow;
though they be red like crimson,
    they shall be as wool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you are willing and obedient,
    you shall eat the good of the land;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
How the faithful city
    has become a prostitute!
She was full of justice;
    righteousness lodged in her,
    but now murderers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your silver has become dross,
    your wine mixed with water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your princes are rebellious
    and companions of thieves;
everyone loves a bribe
    and follows after rewards.
They do not defend the fatherless,
    nor does the cause of the widow come before them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore the Lord, the Lord of Hosts,
    the Mighty One of Israel, says:
Ah, I will get relief from My adversaries,
    and avenge Myself on My enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And I will turn My hand against you,
    thoroughly purge away your dross,
    and take away all your impurities.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will restore your judges as at the first,
    and your counselors as at the beginning.
Afterward you shall be called
    the city of righteousness,
    a faithful town.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Zion shall be redeemed with justice
    and her converts with righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the destruction of the transgressors and sinners shall be together,
    and those who forsake the Lord shall be consumed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For they shall be ashamed of the oaks
    which you have desired,
and you shall be humiliated for the gardens
    that you have chosen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you shall be as an oak whose leaf fades,
    and as a garden that has no water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The strong shall be as tinder,
    and his work like a spark;
they will both burn together,
    and no one will quench them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word that Isaiah the son of Amoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the last days,
the mountain of the Lord’s house shall be established
    on the top of the mountains,
and shall be exalted above the hills,
    and all nations shall flow to it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Many people shall go and say,
“Come, and let us go up to the mountain of the Lord,
    to the house of the God of Jacob,
and He will teach us of His ways,
    and we will walk in His paths.”
For out of Zion shall go forth the law,
    and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
O house of Jacob, come,
    and let us walk in the light of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For You have forsaken Your people,
    the house of Jacob,
because they are replenished from the east,
    and are soothsayers like the Philistines,
    and they please themselves with the children of strangers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their land also is full of silver and gold,
    and there is no end to their treasures;
their land is also full of horses,
    and there is no end to their chariots.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Enter into the rock,
    and hide in the dust
from the fear of the Lord
    and from the glory of His majesty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lofty looks of man shall be humbled,
    and the haughtiness of men shall be bowed down,
and the Lord alone shall be exalted in that day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the day of the Lord of Hosts shall be
    upon everything that is proud and lofty,
    and upon everything that is lifted up,
    and it shall be brought low;
speaker: Narrator

text:
and it will be upon all the cedars of Lebanon that are high and lifted up,
    and upon all the oaks of Bashan,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and upon all the high mountains,
    and upon all the hills that are lifted up,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and upon all the high towers,
    and upon every fenced wall,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and upon all the ships of Tarshish,
    and upon all pleasant sloops.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: the idols He shall utterly abolish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They shall go into the holes of the rocks,
    and into the caves of the earth,
from the fear of the Lord,
    and from the glory of His majesty,
    when He shall arise to shake the earth mightily.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In that day a man shall cast away
    his idols of silver and his idols of gold,
which they made for themselves to worship,
    to the moles and to the bats,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to enter the caverns of the rocks,
    and into the clefts of the cliffs,
from the terror of the Lord,
    and from the glory of His majesty,
    when He arises to shake the earth mightily.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For now the Lord,
    the Lord of Hosts,
takes away from Jerusalem and from Judah
    the stock and the store,
the whole supply of bread, and the whole supply of water;
speaker: Narrator

text:
the mighty man and the man of war,
the judge and the prophet,
    and the prudent and the ancient,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the captain of fifty and the honorable man,
    the counselor and the skillful artisan, and the eloquent orator.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will give youths to be their princes,
    and unweaned children shall rule over them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people shall be oppressed,
    every one by another, and every one by his neighbor;
the youth shall behave himself proudly against the elder,
    and the inferior against the honorable.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When a man shall take hold of his brother
    in the house of his father saying,
“You have clothing; be our ruler,
    and let this ruin be under your power,”
speaker: Narrator

text:
in that day he shall swear saying,
    “I will not be a healer.
For in my house is neither bread nor clothing;
    do not make me a ruler of the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
For Jerusalem is ruined,
    and Judah is fallen,
because their tongue and their deeds are against the Lord,
    to provoke the eyes of His glory.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The expression of their countenance witnesses against them,
    and they declare their sin as Sodom;
    they hide it not.
Woe to them!
    For they have brought evil on themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Say to the righteous that it shall be well with them,
    for they shall eat the fruit of their deeds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to the wicked! It shall be ill with him,
for the reward of his hands shall be given him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As for My people, children are their oppressors,
    and women rule over them.
O My people, those who lead you cause you to err,
    and destroy the way of your paths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord stands up to plead
    and stands to judge the people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord will enter into judgment
    with the elders and the princes of His people:
For you have eaten up the vineyard;
    the spoil of the poor is in your houses.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What do you mean that you beat My people to pieces
    and grind the faces of the poor?
    says the Lord God of Hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moreover the Lord says:
    Because the daughters of Zion are haughty
and walk with outstretched necks
    and wanton eyes,
walking and mincing as they go,
    and making a tinkling with their feet,
speaker: Narrator

text:
therefore, the Lord will strike with a scab the crown of the head of the daughters of Zion,
    and the Lord will make their foreheads bare.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day the Lord will take away the finery of the ankle ornaments, and the headbands, and the crescent ornaments,
speaker: Narrator

text: the chains, and the bracelets, and the veils,
speaker: Narrator

text: the bonnets, the leg ornaments, the sashes, perfume boxes, amulets,
speaker: Narrator

text: the finger rings, nose rings,
speaker: Narrator

text: festal robes, outer tunics, cloaks, purses,
speaker: Narrator

text: hand mirrors, and undergarments, hoods, and veils.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Your men shall fall by the sword,
    and your mighty in the war.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her gates shall lament and mourn,
    and she, being desolate, shall sit on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And in that day seven women
    shall take hold of one man, saying,
“We will eat our own bread,
    and wear our own apparel,
only let us be called by your name,
    to take away our reproach.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day the branch of the Lord shall be beautiful and glorious, and the fruit of the earth shall be excellent and comely for those of Israel who have escaped.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who is left in Zion and he who remains in Jerusalem shall be called holy, even everyone who is written among the living in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord has washed away the filth of the daughters of Zion and has purged the blood of Jerusalem from the midst by the spirit of justice and by the spirit of burning,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the Lord will create upon every dwelling place of Mount Zion, and upon her assemblies, a cloud and smoke by day and the shining of a flaming fire by night. For over all the glory shall be a covering.
speaker: Narrator

text: There shall be a tabernacle for a shadow in the daytime from the heat, and for a place of refuge, and for a shelter from storm and from rain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now I will sing to my well-beloved a song of my beloved
    concerning His vineyard:
My well-beloved has a vineyard
    in a very fruitful hill.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And He fenced it, and removed its stones,
    and planted it with the choicest vine.
And He built a tower in the midst of it,
    and also made a winepress in it;
and He expected it to bring forth good grapes,
    but it brought forth wild grapes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now, O inhabitants of Jerusalem and men of Judah,
    judge between My vineyard and Me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What more could have been done to My vineyard
    that I have not done in it?
Why, when I expected it to bring forth good grapes,
    did it bring forth wild grapes?
speaker: Narrator

text:
So now I will tell you
    what I will do to My vineyard:
I will take away its hedge,
    and it shall be consumed;
I will break down its wall,
    and it shall be trodden down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And I will lay it waste:
    It shall not be pruned or dug,
    but briers and thorns shall come up.
I will also command the clouds
    that they rain no rain on it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the vineyard of the Lord of Hosts
    is the house of Israel,
and the men of Judah
    His pleasant plant.
Thus He looked for justice, but saw oppression;
    for righteousness, but heard a cry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to those who join house to house,
    who add field to field,
until there is no more space
    where they may live alone in the midst of the land!
speaker: Narrator

text:
In my ears the Lord of Hosts said:
Truly, many houses shall be desolate,
    even great and beautiful, without inhabitants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For ten acres of vineyard shall yield one bath,
    and the homer of seed shall yield an ephah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to those who rise up early in the morning
    that they may pursue strong drink;
who continue late in the evening
    until wine inflames them!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lyre and the harp, the tambourine and pipe,
    and wine are in their feasts;
but they do not regard the deeds of the Lord,
    or consider the work of His hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore My people go into captivity
    because they have no knowledge;
and their honorable men are famished,
    and their multitude dried up with thirst.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore Sheol has enlarged itself
    and opened its mouth without measure;
so their glory, and their multitude, and their pomp,
    and he who rejoices shall descend into it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The common man shall be brought down,
    and the great man shall be humbled,
    and the eyes of the lofty shall be humbled.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the Lord of Hosts shall be exalted in judgment,
    and God who is holy shall be hallowed in righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the lambs shall feed in their pasture,
    and strangers shall eat in the waste places of the wealthy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to those who draw iniquity with cords of falsehood
    and sin as if with a cart rope,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who say, “Let Him make speed
    and hasten His work,
    that we may see it;
and let the counsel of the Holy One of Israel
    draw near and come,
    that we may know it!”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Woe to those who are wise in their own eyes
    and prudent in their own sight!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to those who are mighty to drink wine,
    and men of strength to mingle strong drink,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who justify the wicked for a reward,
    and take away the justice of the righteous from him!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, as the fire devours the stubble
    and the flame consumes the chaff,
so their root shall be as rottenness,
    and their blossom shall go up as dust;
because they have cast away the law of the Lord of Hosts
    and despised the word of the Holy One of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore the anger of the Lord burns against His people,
    and He has stretched out His hand against them, and has stricken them,
and the hills trembled.
    Their corpses were torn in the midst of the streets. 
For all this His anger is not turned away,
    and His hand is still stretched out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will lift up a banner to the nations from afar
    and will hiss at them from the ends of the earth;
certainly they shall come
    with speed, swiftly.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
their arrows are sharp
    and all their bows bent;
their horses’ hooves will seem like flint,
    and their wheels like a whirlwind.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
In that day they shall roar against them
    like the roaring of the sea.
And if one looks to the land—
    only darkness and sorrow,
    and the light is darkened by the clouds.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the year that King Uzziah died I saw the Lord sitting on a throne, high and lifted up, and His train filled the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Above it stood the seraphim. Each one had six wings. With two he covered his face, and with two he covered his feet, and with two he flew.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: The posts of the door moved at the voice of him who cried, and the house was filled with smoke.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I said: “Woe is me! For I am undone because I am a man of unclean lips, and I dwell in the midst of a people of unclean lips. For my eyes have seen the King, the Lord of Hosts.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one of the seraphim flew to me with a live coal which he had taken with the tongs from off the altar in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he laid it on my mouth, and said, “This has touched your lips, and your iniquity is taken away, and your sin purged.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Also I heard the voice of the Lord saying, “Whom shall I send, and who will go for us?”
Then I said, “Here am I. Send me.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Make the heart of this people dull,
    and their ears heavy,
    and shut their eyes;
lest they see with their eyes,
    and hear with their ears,
    and understand with their heart,
and turn and be healed.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I said, “Lord, how long?”
And He answered:
“Until the cities are laid waste
    without inhabitants,
and the houses without man,
    and the land is utterly desolate,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and the Lord has removed men far away,
    and there is a great forsaking in the midst of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But yet in it shall be a tenth,
    and it shall return, and shall be burned,
as a terebinth tree or as an oak,
    whose stump remains when it is cut down,
    so the holy seed is its stump.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And it came to pass in the days of Ahaz the son of Jotham, the son of Uzziah, king of Judah, that Rezin the king of Aram, and Pekah the son of Remaliah, king of Israel, went up toward Jerusalem to war against it, but could not prevail against it.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was said to the house of David, “Aram is allied with Ephraim.” Then his heart trembled and the heart of his people, as the trees of the wood tremble with the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Isaiah: Go out now to meet Ahaz, you, and Shear-Jashub your son, at the end of the conduit of the upper pool in the highway of the fuller’s field,
speaker: Narrator

text: and say to him, Take heed, and be quiet. Do not fear nor be fainthearted because of the two tails of these smoking firebrands, because of the fierce anger of Rezin with Aram and of the son of Remaliah,
speaker: Narrator

text: because Aram, Ephraim, and the son of Remaliah have taken evil counsel against you, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us go up against Judah, and trouble it, and let us make a breach there for us, and set a king in the midst of it, even the son of Tabeel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thus says the Lord God:
It shall not stand,
    nor shall it come to pass.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the head of Aram is Damascus,
    and the head of Damascus is Rezin.
Now within sixty-five years
    Ephraim shall be broken so that it is not a people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The head of Ephraim is Samaria,
    and the head of Samaria is the son of Remaliah.
If you will not believe,
    surely you shall not be established.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover the Lord spoke again to Ahaz, saying:
speaker: Narrator

text: Ask for a sign from the Lord your God. Make it either as deep as Sheol or as high as heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Ahaz said, I will not ask, nor will I tempt the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Hear now, O house of David. Is it a small thing for you to weary men, but will you weary my God also?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the Lord Himself shall give you a sign: The virgin shall conceive, and bear a son, and shall call his name Immanuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Curds and honey he shall eat at the time that he knows enough to refuse the evil and choose the good.
speaker: Narrator

text: For before the child shall know to refuse the evil and choose the good, the land that you dread shall be forsaken of both her kings.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord shall bring upon you, and upon your people, and upon your father’s house, days that have not come from the day that Ephraim departed from Judah, even the king of Assyria.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day the Lord shall whistle for the fly that is in the uttermost part of the rivers of Egypt, and for the bee that is in the land of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall come, and all of them shall rest in the desolate valleys, and in the holes of the rocks, and on all thorns, and on all bushes.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that same day the Lord shall shave with a hired razor, from regions beyond the River, with the king of Assyria, the head, and the hair of the legs, and it shall also remove the beard.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day a man shall nourish a young cow and two sheep,
speaker: Narrator

text: and because of the abundance of milk that they give, he shall eat curds; for everyone who is left in the land shall eat curds and honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day every place where there were a thousand vines, worth a thousand shekels of silver, shall become briers and thorns.
speaker: Narrator

text: With arrows and with bows shall men come there because all the land shall become briers and thorns.
speaker: Narrator

text: On all hills that used to be cultivated with the hoe, you will not go there for fear of briers and thorns. But it shall be for pasturing oxen and for sheep to tread.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover the Lord said to me, Take for yourself a large book and write in it with a man’s pen: “Swift is the booty, speedy is the prey.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I will take to Myself faithful witnesses for testimony, Uriah the priest and Zechariah the son of Jeberekiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I went in to the prophetess, and she conceived and bore a son. Then the Lord said to me, Call his name Maher-Shalal-Hash-Baz.
speaker: Narrator

text: For before the child knows how to cry “My father” and “My mother,” the riches of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria shall be taken away before the king of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to me again, saying:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because this people refuses
    the gently flowing waters of Shiloah
and rejoices in Rezin
    and the son of Remaliah,
speaker: Narrator

text:
now therefore the Lord certainly is about to bring upon them
    the strong and plentiful waters of the River,
    even the king of Assyria and all his glory;
and he shall come up over all his channels
    and go over all his banks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And he shall pass through Judah, he shall overflow and go over,
    he shall reach even to the neck,
and the stretching out of his wings shall fill the breadth of your land,
    O Immanuel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Be broken, O you peoples, and be broken in pieces.
    And give ear, all you from far countries.
Gird yourselves, but be broken in pieces;
    gird yourselves, but be broken in pieces.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: For the Lord spoke thus to me with a strong hand and instructed me that I should not walk in the way of this people, saying:
speaker: Narrator

text:
You should not say, “It is a conspiracy,”
    concerning all that this people calls a conspiracy,
neither fear their threats
    nor be afraid of them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sanctify the Lord of Hosts Himself,
    and let Him be your fear,
    and let Him be your dread.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shall become a sanctuary,
    but a stone of stumbling and a rock of offense
to both the houses of Israel,
    and a trap and a snare to the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Many among them shall stumble
    and fall and be broken
    and be snared and be taken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Bind up the testimony;
    seal the law among My disciples.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will wait on the Lord,
    who hides His face from the house of Jacob,
and I will eagerly look for Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, I and the children whom the Lord has given me are for signs and for wonders in Israel from the Lord of Hosts who dwells in Mount Zion.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they say to you, “Seek after the mediums and the wizards, who whisper and mutter,” should not a people seek after their God? Should they consult the dead for the living?
speaker: Narrator

text: To the law and to the testimony; if they do not speak according to this word, it is because there is no light in them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall pass through the land hard-pressed and hungry; when they are hungry, they shall be furious and curse their king and their God as they look upward.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they shall look to the earth and see trouble and darkness, gloom of anguish. And they shall be driven away into darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless there shall be no more gloom for her who was in anguish. In the former time He contemptuously treated the land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali, but in the latter time He shall make it glorious, by the way of the sea, beyond the Jordan, in Galilee of the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people who walked in darkness
    have seen a great light;
those who dwell in the land of the shadow of death,
    upon them the light has shined.

to the place of the name of the Lord of Hosts, even Mount Zion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The oracle of Egypt.
See, the Lord is riding on a swift cloud
    and shall come into Egypt;
and the idols of Egypt shall tremble at His presence,
    and the heart of Egypt shall melt in its midst.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will set the Egyptians against the Egyptians,
    and they shall fight every one against his brother,
    and every one against his neighbor,
    city against city,
    and kingdom against kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The spirit of Egypt shall be discouraged in their midst,
    and I will destroy their counsel;
then they shall seek for the idols and for the charmers
    and for the mediums and the sorcerers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Egyptians I will give over
    into the hand of a cruel lord,
and a fierce king shall rule over them,
    says the Lord, the Lord of Hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The waters from the sea shall dry up,
    and the river shall be parched and dry.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The papyrus reeds by the brooks,
    by the mouth of the brooks,
and everything sown by the brooks,
    shall wither, be driven away, and be no more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fishermen also shall mourn,
    and all those who cast a line into the brooks shall lament,
and those who spread nets on the waters
    shall languish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moreover those who work with fine flax
    and those who weave white cloth shall be humiliated;
speaker: Narrator

text:
and the pillars of Egypt shall be crushed.
    All the hired workers shall be grieved in soul.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely the princes of Zoan are fools;
    the counsel of the wise counselors of Pharaoh has become stupid.
How can you say to Pharaoh,
    “I am a son of the wise,
    a son of ancient kings?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where are they? Where are your wise men?
    Let them tell you now, and let them understand
what the Lord of Hosts
    has purposed against Egypt.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The Lord has mingled
    a perverse spirit in her;
so they have caused Egypt to err in her every work,
    as a drunken man staggers in his vomit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Nor shall there be any work for Egypt,
    which its head or tail, its branch or bulrush, may do.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day Egypt shall become like women. And it shall be afraid and be in dread because of the shaking of the hand of the Lord of Hosts which He is about to shake over it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land of Judah shall become a terror to Egypt. Everyone to whom it is mentioned shall be in dread of it, because of the counsel of the Lord of Hosts which He has determined against it.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day five cities in the land of Egypt shall speak the language of Canaan and swear to the Lord of Hosts. One shall be called the City of Destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day there shall be an altar to the Lord in the midst of the land of Egypt, and a pillar to the Lord at its border.
speaker: Narrator

text: It shall be for a sign and for a witness to the Lord of Hosts in the land of Egypt. For they shall cry to the Lord because of the oppressors, and He shall send them a Savior and a Champion. And He shall deliver them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord shall be known to Egypt, and the Egyptians shall know the Lord in that day, and shall worship with sacrifice and offering, they shall make a vow to the Lord and perform it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord shall strike Egypt. He shall strike and heal it. Then they shall return to the Lord, and He shall be entreated by them and shall heal them.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day there shall be a highway out of Egypt to Assyria, and the Assyrian shall come into Egypt, and the Egyptian into Assyria, and the Egyptians shall worship with the Assyrians.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day Israel shall be the third group with Egypt and Assyria, even a blessing in the midst of the earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: whom the Lord of Hosts has blessed, saying, “Blessed is Egypt My people, and Assyria the work of My hands, and Israel My inheritance.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the year that the Tartan came to Ashdod, when Sargon the king of Assyria sent him, and he fought against Ashdod and took it,
speaker: Narrator

text: at the same time the Lord spoke by Isaiah the son of Amoz saying, “Go and loosen the sackcloth from your waist and take off your shoes from your feet.” And he did so, walking naked and barefoot.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “Even as My servant Isaiah has walked naked and barefoot three years for a sign and wonder against Egypt and Ethiopia,
speaker: Narrator

text: so the king of Assyria shall lead away the Egyptians as prisoners and the Ethiopians as captives, young and old, naked and barefoot, even with their buttocks uncovered, to the shame of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they shall be dismayed and ashamed of Ethiopia their hope and Egypt their boast.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the inhabitants of this coastland shall say in that day, ‘Certainly such is our hope, where we flee for help to be delivered from the king of Assyria! And how shall we escape?’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The oracle of the desert of the sea.
As whirlwinds in the Negev pass through,
    so it comes from the desert,
    from a terrible land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A grievous vision is declared to me;
    the treacherous one still deals treacherously, and the destroyer still destroys.
Go up, O Elam. Lay siege, O Media.
    All her sighing I have made to cease.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
My heart panted,
    fearfulness overwhelmed me;
the night for which I longed
    has turned into trembling for me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Prepare the table,
    watch in the watchtower,
    eat and drink.
Arise, you princes,
    and oil the shields.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
When he sees chariots
    with horsemen in pairs,
a chariot of donkeys,
    and a chariot of camels,
then let him pay close attention,
    very close attention.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the watchman called:
“O Lord, I stand continually on the watchtower in the daytime,
    and I am stationed at my guard post every night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look, here comes a chariot of men,
    horsemen in pairs.”
And he answered and said,
    “Fallen, fallen is Babylon.
And all the graven images of her gods
    lie shattered on the ground.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
O my threshed people and my afflicted of the threshing floor!
    What I have heard from the Lord of Hosts,
the God of Israel,
    I have declared to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The oracle of Dumah.
He calls to me out of Seir,
    “Watchman, how far gone is the night?
    Watchman, how far gone is the night?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The watchman says,
    “The morning comes and also the night.
If you would inquire, inquire;
    return again.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The oracle about Arabia.
In the forest of Arabia you shall lodge,
    O traveling companies of Dedanites.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For they fled from the swords,
    from the drawn sword,
and from the bent bow,
    and from the grievousness of war.
speaker: Narrator

text: For thus the Lord has said to me: Within a year, according to the years of a hireling, all the glory of Kedar shall fail.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the remainder of the number of archers, the mighty men of the children of Kedar, shall be diminished, for the Lord God of Israel has spoken it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The oracle of the Valley of Vision.
What ails you now,
    that you all have gone up to the housetops,
speaker: Narrator

text:
you who were full of noise,
    a tumultuous city, a joyous city?
Your slain are not slain with the sword,
    nor did they die in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All your rulers have fled together;
    they are captured by the archers.
All of you who were found were taken captive together,
    although they had fled from afar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, I say, “Look away from me,
    I will weep bitterly;
do not try to comfort me
    because of the destruction of the daughter of my people.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
For it is a day of trouble and of treading down and of perplexity
    by the Lord God of Hosts
    in the Valley of Vision,
a breaking down of the walls
    and a crying to the mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elam took up the quiver
    with chariots of men and horsemen,
    and Kir uncovered the shield.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your choicest valleys shall be full of chariots,
    and the horsemen shall set themselves in array at the gate.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
you have seen also that the breaches
    of the City of David are many;
and you gathered together the waters
    of the lower pool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have numbered the houses of Jerusalem,
    and the houses you have broken down to fortify the wall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You also made a reservoir between the two walls
    for the water of the old pool.
But you have not looked to its Maker,
    nor did you respect Him who fashioned it long ago.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In that day the Lord God of Hosts
    called you to weeping and mourning,
    and to tear your hair and wear sackcloth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet, there is joy and gladness,
    slaying of oxen and killing of sheep,
    eating of meat and drinking wine:
“Let us eat and drink,
    for tomorrow we may die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: It was revealed in my hearing by the Lord of Hosts: Surely this iniquity shall not be forgiven you until you die, says the Lord God of Hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thus says the Lord God of Hosts:
Come, go to this treasurer,
    even to Shebna, who is over the royal household, and say:
speaker: Narrator

text:
What right do you have here? And whom do you have here
    that you have dug out for yourself a tomb here,
as he who hews out for himself a tomb on high,
    and who cuts a habitation for himself in a rock?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, the Lord is about to hurl you headlong, O man;
    He is about to seize you firmly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will surely violently turn
    and toss you like a ball into a large country;
there you shall die,
    and there the chariots of your glory shall be
    the shame of your lord’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will drive you from your office
    and pull you down from your station.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day I will call My servant Eliakim the son of Hilkiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will clothe him with your robe and tie him securely with your sash. And I will entrust him with your authority, and he shall be a father to the inhabitants of Jerusalem and to the house of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The key of the house of David I will lay on his shoulder. Then he shall open, and no one shall shut. And he shall shut, and no one shall open.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will fasten him as a nail in a firm place, and he shall become a glorious throne to his father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall hang on him all the glory of his father’s house, the offspring and the issue, all vessels of small quantity, from the bowls to all the jars.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day, says the Lord of Hosts, the nail that is fastened in the firm place shall be removed, and be cut down and fall. And the load that was on it shall be cut off, for the Lord has spoken it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The oracle of Tyre.
Wail, O ships of Tarshish,
    for Tyre is laid waste
    so that there is no house or harbor;
from the land of Cyprus
    it is reported to them.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Be ashamed, O Sidon; for the sea has spoken,
    even the stronghold of the sea, saying,
“I have not travailed nor brought forth children;
    neither have I brought up young men nor raised virgins.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the report reaches Egypt,
    they shall be sorely pained at the report of Tyre.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pass over to Tarshish;
    wail, O inhabitants of the coastland.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is this your joyous city,
    whose origin is from ancient days,
whose feet used to carry her
    to sojourn in distant locations?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has planned this against Tyre,
    the crowning city,
whose merchants are princes,
    whose traffickers are the honorable of the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord of Hosts has purposed it,
    to stain the pride of all glory
    and to bring into contempt all the honorable of the earth.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
He stretched out His hand over the sea,
    He shook the kingdoms;
the Lord has given a command against the merchant city,
    to destroy its strongholds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said: You shall rejoice no more,
    O oppressed virgin daughter of Sidon. 
Arise, pass over to Cyprus;
    there also you shall have no rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look at the land of the Chaldeans;
    this was a people who was not;
Assyria founded it
    for those who dwell in the wilderness.
They set up their siege towers,
    they stripped its palaces,
    and brought it to ruin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wail, O ships of Tarshish,
    for your stronghold is laid waste.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day Tyre shall be forgotten for seventy years, according to the days of one king. After the end of seventy years Tyre shall sing as a harlot:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take your harp, go about the city,
    O forgotten harlot;
make sweet melody, sing many songs,
    that you may be remembered.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of seventy years, the Lord will punish Tyre. Then she shall turn to her harlot’s wages and shall commit fornication with all the kingdoms on the face of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her merchandise and her harlot’s wages shall be set apart to the Lord. It shall not be treasured nor stored up, for her merchandise shall be for those who dwell before the Lord, to eat sufficiently, and for choice clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now the Lord makes the earth empty,
    and makes it waste,
and turns it upside down,
    and scatters its inhabitants abroad.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The land shall be utterly emptied,
    and utterly despoiled,
    for the Lord has spoken this word.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The earth mourns and fades away,
    the world languishes and fades away,
    the haughty people of the earth languish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The earth also is defiled by its inhabitants
    because they have transgressed the laws,
violated the ordinances,
    broken the everlasting covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, the curse devours the earth,
    and those who dwell in it are held guilty.
Therefore, the inhabitants of the earth are burned,
    and few men are left.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The new wine fails, the vine languishes,
    all the merry-hearted sigh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The joy of tambourines ceases,
    the noise of those who rejoice ends,
    the joy of the harp ceases.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They shall not drink wine with song;
    strong drink shall be bitter to those who drink it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The city of confusion is broken down;
    every house is shut up so that no one may come in.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is an outcry for wine in the streets,
    all joy is turned to gloom,
    the joyfulness of the earth is gone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Desolation is left in the city,
    and the gate is battered to destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For thus it shall be in the midst of the earth
    among the peoples,
as the shaking of an olive tree,
    and as the gleaning of grapes when the vintage is done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They lift up their voices; they sing for the majesty of the Lord;
    they cry aloud from the west.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore glorify the Lord in the east,
    even the name of the Lord God of Israel
    in the coastlands of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the uttermost part of the earth we hear songs,
    that is, “Glory to the Righteous One.” 
But I say, Woe to me! Woe to me!
    Alas for me!
The treacherous deal treacherously;
    indeed, the treacherous deal very treacherously.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Terror and the pit and the snare are upon you,
    O inhabitant of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He who flees from the report of disaster
    shall fall into the pit,
and he who comes up out of the midst of the pit
    shall be taken in the snare. 
For the windows from on high are open,
    and the foundations of the earth shake.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The earth is utterly broken down,
    the earth is split through,
    the earth is shaken violently.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The earth reels to and fro like a drunkard,
    and it totters like a shack,
and its transgression is heavy upon it,
    and it shall fall, never to rise again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In that day the Lord shall punish
    the host of heaven on high
    and the kings of the earth on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They shall be gathered together,
    as prisoners are gathered in the dungeon,
and shall be shut up in the prison,
    and after many days they shall be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the moon shall be humiliated and the sun ashamed,
    when the Lord of Hosts reigns
in Mount Zion and in Jerusalem,
    and His glory shall be before His elders.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord, You are my God.
    I will exalt You, I will praise Your name,
for You have done wonderful things;
    Your plans formed of old
    are faithfulness and truth.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Therefore a strong people shall glorify You;
    cities of ruthless nations shall fear You.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For You have been a defense to the poor,
    a defense to the needy in his distress,
a refuge from the storm,
    a shadow from the heat;
for the breath of the ruthless ones
    is as a storm against the wall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You bring down the noise of strangers,
as heat in drought;
    as the heat by the shadow of a cloud,
    the song of the ruthless ones shall be brought low.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In this mountain the Lord of Hosts shall prepare
    for all people a lavish feast,
a feast of aged wines,
    choice pieces full of marrow, and refined, aged wines.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will destroy in this mountain
    the covering which is over all peoples,
even the veil that is spread over all nations.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
It shall be said in that day:
Look, this is our God
    for whom we have waited that He might save us.
This is the Lord for whom we have waited;
    we will be glad and rejoice in His salvation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For in this mountain the hand of the Lord shall rest,
    and Moab shall be trodden down in his place
    as straw is trodden down in the water for the manure pile.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shall spread out his hands in the midst of it,
    as a swimmer spreads out his hands to swim,
yet the Lord shall bring down his pride
    together with the trickery of his hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The unassailable fortresses of your walls
    He shall bring down, lay low,
and bring to the ground,
    even to the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In that day this song shall be sung in the land of Judah:
We have a strong city;
    He appoints walls
    and bulwarks for security.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Open the gates,
    that the righteous nation may enter,
    the one who remains faithful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will keep him in perfect peace,
    whose mind is stayed on You,
    because he trusts in You.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Trust in the Lord forever,
    for in God the Lord we have an everlasting rock.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For He brings down those who dwell on high,
    the lofty city; He lays it low; He lays it low,
even to the ground;
    He brings it even to the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The foot shall tread it down,
    even the feet of the poor
    and the steps of the needy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The way of the righteous is smooth;
    O Upright One, make the path of the righteous level.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the way of Your judgments, O Lord,
    we have waited for You eagerly;
the desire of our souls is Your name,
    even Your memory.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Though favor is shown to the wicked,
    yet he will not learn righteousness;
in the land of uprightness he deals unjustly
    and does not perceive the majesty of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lord, Your hand is lifted up,
    but they do not see it.
They see Your zeal for the people and are put to shame;
    the fire of Your enemies shall devour them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lord, You will ordain peace for us,
    for You also have done all our works for us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord our God, other lords besides You have had dominion over us,
    but through You alone we confess Your name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The dead shall not live;
    the departed spirits shall not rise.
Therefore, You have punished and destroyed them
    and made all remembrance of them to perish.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Like a woman with child, who is in pain and cries out in her pangs
    when she draws near the time of her delivery,
    so have we been in Your sight, O Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We have been with child, we have been in pain,
    we have, as it were, brought forth wind;
we have not accomplished any deliverance in the earth,
    nor were the inhabitants of the world born.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your dead shall live,
    their corpses shall arise.
Awake and sing,
    you who dwell in dust,
for your dew is as the dew of the dawn,
    and the earth shall give birth to the departed spirits.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come, my people, enter your chambers,
    and shut your doors behind you;
hide for a little while
    until the indignation is over.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord comes out of His place
    to punish the inhabitants of the earth for their iniquity;
the earth also shall disclose her bloodshed
    and shall cover her slain no more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In that day
the Lord with His fierce and great
    and strong sword shall punish
Leviathan the fleeing serpent,
    even Leviathan the twisted serpent;
and He shall slay the dragon that is in the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In that day:
Sing of it! A vineyard of red wine.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I have no fury.
Should someone give Me briers and thorns in battle,
    then I would step on them,
    I would burn them fully.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Has He struck them,
    as He struck those who struck them?
Or like the slaughter of His slain,
    have they been slain?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You fought with them by banishing them, by driving them away.
    He has expelled them
    on the day of the east wind with His fierce wind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Through this, therefore, the iniquity of Jacob shall be forgiven,
    and this will be the full price of the removal of his sin:
when he makes all the stones of the altar
    as chalkstones that are pulverized,
when the groves and incense altars
    shall not stand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the fortified city shall be desolate,
    a homestead forlorn and forsaken like a wilderness;
there the calf shall graze,
    and there it shall lie down
    and eat its branches.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: In that day the Lord shall thresh from the channel of the River to the stream of Egypt, and you shall be gathered one by one, O sons of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And in that day the great trumpet shall be blown, and those who were ready to perish in the land of Assyria and the outcasts in the land of Egypt shall worship the Lord in the holy mount at Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to the proud crown of the drunkards of Ephraim,
    whose glorious beauty is a fading flower
which is at the head of the fertile valley
    of those who are overcome with wine!
speaker: Narrator

text:
See, the Lord has a mighty and strong one,
    as a tempest of hail and a destroying storm,
as a flood of mighty overflowing waters,
    He has cast it down to the earth with His hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The proud crown of the drunkards of Ephraim
    is trodden under foot;
speaker: Narrator

text:
and the fading flower of its glorious beauty,
    which is at the head of the fertile valley,
shall be like a first-ripe fig before the summer,
    which when one sees, while it is yet in his hand,
    he eats it up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In that day the Lord of Hosts
    shall become a crown of glory
and a diadem of beauty
    to the remnant of His people,
speaker: Narrator

text:
a spirit of justice
    for him who sits in judgment,
and strength
    to those who turn away the battle at the gate.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But they also have erred through wine
    and stagger from strong drink;
the priest and the prophet have erred through strong drink,
    they are confused by wine,
they stagger from strong drink;
    they err while having visions,
    they stumble when rendering judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For all the tables are full of vomit
    and filthiness so that there is no clean place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“To whom shall He teach knowledge,
    and to whom shall He interpret the message?
Those just weaned from the milk
    and drawn from the breasts?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For He says,
    ‘Precept upon precept, precept upon precept,
    line upon line, line upon line,
    here a little, there a little.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text:
For with stammering lips and foreign tongue
    He will speak to this people,
speaker: Narrator

text:
He who said to them,
    “This is the rest. Give rest to the weary,”
and, “This is repose,”
    yet they would not listen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the word of the Lord will be to them,
    “Precept upon precept, precept upon precept,
    line upon line, line upon line,
    here a little, there a little,”

text: nor let Hezekiah make you trust in the Lord, saying, The Lord will surely deliver us. This city shall not be delivered into the hand of the king of Assyria.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do not listen to Hezekiah, for thus says the king of Assyria: ‘Make your peace with me and come out to me, and eat every one of his vine and every one of his fig tree, and drink every one the waters of his own cistern,
speaker: Narrator

text: until I come and take you away to a land like your own land, a land of corn and new wine, a land of bread and vineyards.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘Beware lest Hezekiah persuade you, saying, The Lord will deliver us. Has any one of the gods of the nations delivered his land out of the hand of the king of Assyria?
speaker: Narrator

text: Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim? And when have they delivered Samaria out of my hand?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who are they among all the gods of these lands that have delivered their land out of my hand, that the Lord should deliver Jerusalem out of my hand?’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they held their peace, and answered him not a word, for the king’s commandment was, “Do not answer him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliakim the son of Hilkiah, who was over the household, and Shebna the scribe, and Joah the son of Asaph, the recorder, came to Hezekiah with their clothes torn and told him the words of the Rabshakeh.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it came to pass when King Hezekiah heard it that he tore his clothes, and covered himself with sackcloth, and went into the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent Eliakim, who was over the household, and Shebna the scribe, and the elders of the priests, covered with sackcloth, to Isaiah the prophet, the son of Amoz.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “Thus says Hezekiah: This day is a day of trouble, and of rebuke, and of blasphemy. For children have come to birth, and there is no strength to bring them forth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Perhaps the Lord your God will hear the words of the Rabshakeh, whom the king of Assyria his master has sent to reproach the living God, and will reprove the words which the Lord your God has heard. Therefore, lift up a prayer for the remnant that is left.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the servants of King Hezekiah came to Isaiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaiah said to them, “Thus you shall say to your master, ‘Thus says the Lord: Do not be afraid of the words that you have heard, with which the servants of the king of Assyria have blasphemed Me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen! I will put a spirit in him so that he shall hear a rumor, and return to his own land. And I will cause him to fall by the sword in his own land.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Rabshakeh returned and found the king of Assyria warring against Libnah. For he had heard that the king had left Lachish.
speaker: Narrator

text: He heard them say concerning Tirhakah king of Ethiopia, “He has come out to make war with you.” And when he heard it, he sent messengers to Hezekiah, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Thus you shall speak to Hezekiah king of Judah, saying: Do not let your God in whom you trust deceive you, saying, ‘Jerusalem shall not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Certainly you have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all lands by utterly destroying them. So shall you be delivered?
speaker: Narrator

text: Have the gods of the nations delivered them which my fathers have destroyed, even Gozan and Harran and Rezeph and the sons of Eden who were in Tel Assar?
speaker: Narrator

text: Where is the king of Hamath, and the king of Arpad, and the kings of the city of Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivvah?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Hezekiah received the letter from the hand of the messengers and read it. Then Hezekiah went up to the house of the Lord, and spread it before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hezekiah prayed to the Lord, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “O Lord of Hosts, God of Israel, who dwells above the cherubim, You are the God, even You alone, of all the kingdoms of the earth. You have made heaven and earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Incline Your ear, O Lord, and hear. Open Your eyes, O Lord, and see, and hear all the words of Sennacherib, which he has sent to reproach the living God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Truly, O Lord, the kings of Assyria have laid waste all the nations and their countries,
speaker: Narrator

text: and have cast their gods into the fire. For they were not gods, but the work of men’s hands, wood and stone. Therefore, they have destroyed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, O Lord our God, save us from his hand that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that You alone, Lord, are God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaiah the son of Amoz sent to Hezekiah, saying, “Thus says the Lord God of Israel: Because you have prayed to Me about Sennacherib king of Assyria,
speaker: Narrator

text:
this is the word which the Lord has spoken against him:
The virgin daughter of Zion

the daughter of Jerusalem
    has shaken her head at you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whom have you reproached and blasphemed?

and lifted up your eyes haughtily?

Through your servants

and have said,

I have come up to the heights of the mountains,

and I will go to its highest peak,

text:
I have dug wells

text:

text:

text: Then the angel of the Lord went out and struck one hundred eighty-five thousand in the camp of the Assyrians. When others woke up early in the morning, these were all dead bodies.

text: So Sennacherib king of Assyria departed and returned home and lived in Nineveh.

text: It came to pass as he was worshipping in the house of Nisrok, his god, that Adrammelek and Sharezer, his sons, struck him with the sword, and they escaped into the land of Ararat. And Esarhaddon his son reigned in his stead.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days Hezekiah was mortally ill. And Isaiah the prophet, the son of Amoz, came to him and said to him, “Thus says the Lord: Set your house in order, for you shall die, and not live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Hezekiah turned his face toward the wall, and prayed to the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, “Remember now, O Lord, I beseech You, how I have walked before You in truth and with a perfect heart, and have done what is good in Your sight.” And Hezekiah wept bitterly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the word of the Lord came to Isaiah, saying:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go, and say to Hezekiah, Thus says the Lord, the God of David your father: I have heard your prayer, I have seen your tears. Surely I will add to your days fifteen years.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will deliver you and this city out of the hand of the king of Assyria, and I will defend this city.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This shall be a sign to you from the Lord, that the Lord will do this thing that He has spoken:
speaker: Narrator

text: I will cause the shadow on the sundial, which has gone down with the sun on the sundial of Ahaz, to go back ten steps.” So the sun’s shadow returned ten steps on the sundial by which it had gone down.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the writing of Hezekiah king of Judah after his illness and recovery:

Narrator

text: At that time Marduk-Baladan the son of Baladan, king of Babylon, sent letters and a present to Hezekiah, for he had heard that he had been sick and had recovered.

text: Hezekiah was glad and showed them the house of his precious things: the silver, and the gold, and the spices, and the precious ointment, and his whole armory, and all that was found in his treasuries. There was nothing in his house, nor in all his dominion, that Hezekiah did not show them.

text:

text: Then Isaiah said to Hezekiah, “Hear the word of the Lord of Hosts.

text: Then Hezekiah said to Isaiah, “The word of the Lord which you have spoken is good.” For he said, “For there shall be peace and truth in my days.”
